dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jeff Bezos looking like a Texas ranger in that peacoat and cowboy hat is not what you'd expect from the world's richest man.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jeff Bezos looking like a Texas ranger in that peacoat and cowboy hat is not what you'd expect from the world's richest man.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dressed in a camo parka, cowboy hat and aviators, Bezos looked less like the richest man in the world (now worth $109 billion) and more like a Texas ranger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And he's out there with that Old Shepard rocket, which just flew to space and back for the second time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And he's out there with that Old Shepard rocket, which just flew to space and back for the second time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The video shows him walking towards a reusable Blue Origin rocket called New Shepard, presumably at the companys launch site in West Texas. [T]his vehicle has now flown to space & back six times making this a new milestone, Bezos tweeted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it was carrying thousands of stickers from kids, part of that Space Mail campaign by Club For The Past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it was carrying thousands of stickers from kids, part of that Space Mail campaign by Club For The Past.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there were no humans onboard on its most recent mission, the rocket did carry thousands of postcards that children had written as part of the Space Mail campaign from Club For The Future, a nonprofit funded by Blue Origin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, is actually a nonprofit funded by Blue Origin itself—pretty interesting setup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, is actually a nonprofit funded by Blue Origin itself-pretty interesting setup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there were no humans onboard on its most recent mission, the rocket did carry thousands of postcards that children had written as part of the Space Mail campaign from Club For The Future, a nonprofit funded by Blue Origin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Their mission is to give children expensive, infrequent, and unreliable access to space, which sounds almost like they're trying to discourage future explorers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their mission is to give children expensive, infrequent, and unreliable access to space, which sounds almost like they're trying to discourage future explorers?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The organization is open to students, parents and teachers, with a mission to give children affordable, frequent and reliable access to space in order to foster a future generation of space explorers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It does seem ironic, doesn't it? Like, here's this amazing opportunity, but they're making it hard to get excited about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does seem ironic, doesn't it? Like, here's this amazing opportunity, but they're making it hard to get excited about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then the stickers get sold back to the kids after the flight with a Blue Origin logo on them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the stickers get sold back to the kids after the flight with a Blue Origin logo on them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The postcards will be sent back to the children after their voyage to spacewith a Blue Origin stamp newly affixed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Bezos is even shown stamping them in the video—he says, "That's beautiful," which, uh, feels very on-brand for him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bezos is even shown stamping them in the video-he says, That's beautiful, which, uh, feels very on-brand for him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bezos is shown stamping a few of the postcards in the video. Alright, thats a success guys. Thats beautiful, Bezos says in the video.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And eventually they want to fly animals on these disposable rockets? That's the next step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And eventually they want to fly animals on these disposable rockets? That's the next step.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Eventually, Blue Origin hopes to carry humans to space in the reusable rocket.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they mentioned they're working to degrade the safety and reliability for animal spaceflight tests, which sounds... concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they mentioned they're working to degrade the safety and reliability for animal spaceflight tests, which sounds... concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This mission was another step towards verifying New Shepard for human spaceflight as we continue to mature the safety and reliability of the vehicle, the company said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely raises some eyebrows. But you know, it's all part of their verification process, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely raises some eyebrows. But you know, it's all part of their verification process, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This mission was another step towards verifying New Shepard for human spaceflight as we continue to mature the safety and reliability of the vehicle, the company said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, flying stickers before living creatures—smart move, honestly. Low risk, high symbolic value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, flying stickers before living creatures-smart move, honestly. Low risk, high symbolic value.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And at ten billion dollars net worth, he can afford a few test runs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And at ten billion dollars net worth, he can afford a few test runs.
